title: offering Korean classes for the foreign KAIST (registration period： Sept. 5)
content:
Korean Class (Non-Credit Course)
at KAIST Language Center!!!

KAIST Language Center is offering Korean classes for the foreign KAIST students, faculty, their family, and postdoctoral at KAIST.

Registration 
 - Term: 2006 Fall Semester
 - Registration Period: by Sept. 5, 2006

- How to register a class
1. Go to the Language Center homepage (http://lang.kaist.ac.kr/english)
   2. Click “Join” to create your ID (if you have your own ID already, go to #3)
   3. Log in with your ID and PW
   4. Click “Study Programs” and register class you want

Syllabus for Basic Korean (Fall 2006)

Instructor : Deokshin  Kim
Office hours: by appointments
E-mail: rytn1@dreamwiz.com
Classes: Basic, Tues. & Thurs., 6:30 to 7:20 pm, CLR 1408                         
Course Description :Designed for individuals with no former knowledge of Korean. Students begin by learning vowels, consonants, and pronunciation and will eventually be able to conduct basic conversation in Korea. Students will learn the skills of listening, speaking, reading and writing in Korean.

Materials  : Hand-outs

Syllabus for Intermediate Korean (Fall 2006)

Instructor : Deokshin  Kim
Office hours: by appointments
E-mail: rytn1@dreamwiz.com
Classes: Korean 2, Tues, & Thurs., 7:30 to 9:20 pm, CLR 1408                         
Course Description : Students in this course are assumed to have previous knowledge of Korean that was taught in Korean 1. Students will learn the skills of listening, speaking, reading and writing in Korean.

Materials : 한국어2 (Korean2) (handouts)
                        
Course Requirements and Evaluation:
Attendance…………………10%             
Class Assignments…………10%   
Midterm.……………………40%
Final….. ……………………40%

Grading:  The percentage figures give above are only used as "guidelines."  Final grades will be adjusted taking into consideration the "grade curve," i.e. the distribution of all students’ grade points.

Minimum Grade: In order to advance to the next level, a student must achieve a grade of "C" or better.

Class Participation: When a student is observed not eagerly participating in class activities (talking in English, studying for other classes, taking a nap etc.), some points (1-10%) will be extracted from their final score. When doing something else other than instructed in the lab(internet surfing or emailing),  you cannot get A or A- and the final grade will be lowered. 

Absences: Points will be subtracted from your final score (0.5% per absence) for inexcusable absences and tardiness.
        Over 10 absences: you can not get over C grade.
        Over 5 absences: you can not get A or A-.

Excusable Absences: Absences can be excused in case of illness, family emergency, and other unforeseeable incidents beyond the control of a student. A signed note from a person who can verify the absence (e.g. a note from a doctor in case of illness) and his/her phone number are required.
